comments.content: Why not C? An IP Pool is basically a range of IP addresses. Firewall policies > Source: "IP Address, user or Internet Services" - Security 6.4 p 102.
FQDN is an option for address. You can select an ip address not an ip pool. So B&D is correct.

discussion.content:
C & D are correct - FGT_Security-6.2, p.104
B is not correct because "FQDN address" is not a correct definition

questions.question_text: Which two configuration objects can you select in for the Source field of a firewall policy? (Choose two.)
Which actions can be applied to each filter in the application control profile?

discussion.content:
A is correct answer.
Since both A and B are working options, answer B needs one more Web filter profile - the one that will allow access to the category in which resides website's domain name.
In both cases a custom category is needed and a rating override, which will assign the website to that category.
The question is "Which configuration option is the most effective way to support this request" in that case this is answer A
For me A sounds correct, not B
A and B are correct, in 7.0 there's two answer for this question.
For me it is ok the B, since the authentication is to a category not to a specific url.

choices.C: Implement DNS filter for the specified website.
choices.B: Implement a web filter category override for the specified website.
choices.A: Implement web filter authentication for the specified website.
choices.D: Implement web filter quotas for the specified website.

questions.question_text:
A team manager has decided that, while some members of the team need access to a particular website, the majority of the team does not.
Which configuration option is the most effective way to support this request?

choices.A: It selects the first matching central SNAT policy, reviewing from top to bottom.
choices.C: It selects the SNAT policy specified in the configuration of the firewall policy that matches the traffic.
choices.D: It selects the central SNAT policy with the lowest priority
choices.B: It selects the SNAT policy specified in the configuration of the outgoing interface.

questions.question_text: How does FortiGate select the central SNAT policy that is applied to a TCP session?

discussion.content: B & C are correct - FGT_Enterprise_FW-6.2, p.219

comments.content: Also note that all: is not a VDOM but the checksum of the global configuration plus checksum of all the VDOMs. Infrastructure 6.2 - p.324

discussion.content: There is a mismatch in these question. The All VDOM is not synchr? it suppose to be all VDOM are not synchr. VDOM name root are not synchronized and the VDOM name all are also not synchronized. The global vdom si the only one who is synchronized. There are 3 correct answers

comments.content: Yeah A,B and C, I suggest

choices.A: The all VDOM is not synchronized between the primary and secondary FortiGate devices.
choices.B: The global configuration is synchronized between the primary and secondary FortiGate devices.
choices.C: The root VDOM is not synchronized between the primary and secondary FortiGate devices.
choices.D: The FortiGate devices have three VDOMs.
